meta.chapter: Chapter 6 – The Role of Standards and Frameworks: From Fragmentation to Cohesion
meta.notes: Items first; answer key at the end to match exam-like experience.
sources: Study Guide Ch.6 (6.1–6.4): roles of standard‑setters; formative standards and frameworks; frameworks vs standards; industry-agnostic vs industry-specific; consolidation into ISSB

items.stem: In capital markets, what is the central role of sustainability disclosure standard‑setters?
options: To conduct assurance engagements over sustainability reports
To enable consistent, investor‑useful disclosure by defining what companies should report and how
To lobby governments to ban non‑financial reporting
To rate corporate bonds using proprietary risk models
items.explanation: Standard‑setters provide the information infrastructure: they set criteria so companies disclose decision‑useful sustainability information consistently across the market.

items.stem: Which statement best distinguishes a disclosure framework from a disclosure standard?
options: Frameworks prescribe specific metrics; standards provide only high‑level concepts
Frameworks structure ‘how’ to prepare and contextualize information; standards specify ‘what’ topics/metrics to disclose for comparability
There is no practical difference between them
Standards are always voluntary; frameworks are always mandatory
items.explanation: Frameworks (e.g., TCFD, CDSB, Integrated Reporting) organize the preparation and structure; standards (e.g., SASB, many GRI topics) enumerate specific topics/metrics to enable comparison.

items.stem: Which pairing is MOST accurate regarding audience orientation?
options: SASB → all stakeholders equally
GRI → primarily investors and lenders only
TCFD → investors, with guidance for mainstream filings
IIRC → retail consumers only
items.explanation: TCFD was designed to inform investors via disclosures aligned to governance, strategy, risk management, and metrics/targets, often in mainstream filings.

items.stem: Which TWO examples illustrate why industry‑specific standards matter? (Choose two)
options: Auto manufacturers: vehicle use‑phase fuel economy is financially relevant to climate risk
Meat & dairy producers: Scope 1 process emissions are central to operations
All industries face identical climate KPIs; industry context is irrelevant
Only qualitative storytelling is needed; metrics impede investor analysis
items.explanation: Climate risk manifests differently by industry; use‑phase metrics for autos and direct operational emissions for meat/dairy are salient, supporting industry‑specific disclosures.

items.stem: Which event sequence best explains the path to creating the ISSB under the IFRS Foundation?
options: Private merger of GRI with IASB, followed by elimination of SASB
Public consultation by IFRS Foundation and joint Statement of Intent by leading bodies, followed by consolidation of CDSB and VRF and the launch of ISSB
Regulators mandated a single EU‑only standard, then ISSB adopted it
TNFD replaced TCFD, which directly created the ISSB
items.explanation: Market demand led to the IFRS consultation and a joint Statement of Intent; thereafter CDSB and VRF were consolidated, culminating in the creation of the ISSB.

items.stem: Which TWO issues were associated with fragmented voluntary disclosure before consolidation? (Choose two)
options: Alphabet‑soup confusion and inconsistent adoption across regions
Over‑standardization that prevented any flexibility for preparers
Abundance of immaterial or non‑comparable information for investors
Universal assurance at reasonable cost for all reporters
items.explanation: Multiple bodies and varied adoption created confusion and non‑comparability; investors faced noise and inconsistent metrics.

items.stem: Under the TCFD recommendations, which thematic area is part of the core structure?
options: Tax strategy
Governance
Shareholder activism policy
Dividend distribution policy
items.explanation: TCFD recommends disclosures organized under governance, strategy, risk management, and metrics & targets.

items.stem: The IFRS Sustainability Disclosure Standards were designed by building on which TWO investor‑focused resources? (Choose two)
options: SASB Standards
CDSB Framework
GRI impact materiality alone
UN Global Compact Communication on Progress as a standard
items.explanation: IFRS SDS build on investor‑focused resources including SASB and CDSB (alongside TCFD and others).

items.stem: Which statement best captures regulators’ stance toward TCFD by 2021?
options: No regulator publicly supported TCFD
Support from over a hundred public authorities, with several jurisdictions announcing requirements aligned to TCFD
Only one small jurisdiction supported TCFD
TCFD was replaced by TNFD in all markets
items.explanation: Authorities in multiple jurisdictions supported or moved toward TCFD‑aligned requirements.

items.stem: Which pairing best matches organization and its original orientation?
options: CDP → investor‑only climate metrics with no stakeholder uses
IIRC → integrated reporting framework aimed at investors’ holistic view
SASB → impact‑materiality for stakeholders broadly
TNFD → mandatory standard for assurance engagements
items.explanation: IIRC created the Integrated Reporting Framework to bring financial and non‑financial information together for investors’ holistic understanding.

items.stem: Order these events from earliest to latest in the consolidation journey: (1) Statement of Intent by CDP/CDSB/GRI/IIRC/SASB, (2) IFRS consultation on sustainability reporting, (3) ISSB launch with CDSB and VRF consolidation, (4) Publication of prototype requirements. Which is correct?
items.explanation: The joint statement and IFRS consultation were concurrent drivers; prototypes preceded the formal ISSB launch and consolidations.

items.stem: Which option orders these resources from MORE industry‑agnostic toward MORE industry‑specific?
options: IIRC → CDSB → TCFD → SASB
SASB → TCFD → CDSB → IIRC
TCFD → SASB → IIRC → CDSB
GRI (sector standards) → SASB → TCFD → IIRC
items.explanation: IIRC and CDSB are highly agnostic; TCFD adds structure with some sector supplements; SASB is explicitly industry‑specific.

items.stem: Which TWO statements reflect how standards complement frameworks? (Choose two)
options: Standards’ specificity enables apples‑to‑apples comparison across firms
Frameworks replace the need for metrics entirely
Frameworks help structure governance/strategy/risk disclosures for rigor similar to financial reporting
Standards make assurance more feasible by defining replicable measures
items.explanation: Frameworks structure the reporting process; standards add specific metrics enabling comparison and facilitating assurance readiness.

items.stem: Which statement best describes the market shift noted in Chapter 6 regarding adoption?
options: A move from purely voluntary use toward increasing regulatory adoption/requirements
A universal rejection of sustainability reporting by exchanges
Immediate global mandate for a single EU standard
Return to unstructured CSR narratives only
items.explanation: Markets began shifting from voluntary frameworks toward mandated or recommended alignment with specific guidance.

items.stem: Which TWO practices characterize the IFRS Foundation’s approach to standard‑setting and helped the IASB/ISSB achieve broad adoption? (Choose two)
options: Globally representative governance and consultative processes
Closed‑door decision‑making without public input
Robust due process engaging preparers, users and regulators
Exclusive focus on one region’s needs
items.explanation: Global governance and robust due process with market input underpin legitimacy and adoption.

items.stem: Which TWO statements BEST justify consolidation under a single investor‑focused baseline? (Choose two)
options: Improves consistency and comparability of information across markets
Ensures every stakeholder objective is equally prioritized in one document regardless of investor needs
Reduces ‘alphabet soup’ complexity for preparers and users
Eliminates the need to consider industry‑specific topics
items.explanation: Consolidation addresses comparability and complexity; it does not eliminate industry specificity nor flatten stakeholder nuances.

items.stem: Which is MOST accurate regarding GRI and SASB as originally designed?
options: Both are primarily investor‑focused standards
GRI focuses on broader stakeholder impacts; SASB focuses on investor‑relevant topics and metrics
SASB is a framework; GRI is a financial accounting standard
Neither has ever been used alongside frameworks
items.explanation: GRI targets broad impacts and stakeholders; SASB targets investor‑relevant, industry‑specific disclosure topics and metrics.

items.stem: What was the status/purpose of TNFD during the period described?
options: A mandatory global standard enforced by IOSCO
A developing framework to help organizations assess and disclose nature‑related risks/opportunities
A replacement for the TCFD recommendations in financial filings
A sector‑specific standard for the utilities industry only
items.explanation: TNFD was being developed as a framework to guide risk/opportunity management and disclosure on nature‑related issues.

items.stem: Which TWO outcomes can follow when companies apply only high‑level frameworks without standard specificity? (Choose two)
options: Inconsistent units/metrics limiting comparability
Greater ease of assurance due to uniform metrics
Potential omission of industry‑salient topics
Automatic alignment with investor needs across industries
items.explanation: Frameworks alone may yield inconsistencies and overlook industry‑salient information that standards make explicit.

items.stem: What is the stated purpose of establishing the ISSB’s global baseline of sustainability disclosure standards?
options: Replace financial reporting with ESG narratives
Provide a consistent, investor‑focused foundation that jurisdictions can build upon
Mandate identical sustainability strategies for all companies
Eliminate regional regulatory input
items.explanation: A global baseline enables consistent, investor‑focused information while allowing jurisdictions to build on it.
